Personally, I wouldn't recommend playing NIOH1 and NIOH2 back-to-back in one sitting, as the two games share significant repetition. Playing for extended periods straight can lead to severe fatigue. If you only plan to play through the game once casually, focusing primarily on the story and combat, then it's not a major issue. However, if you intend to thoroughly explore every detail, play through at least four times, and ultimately unlock all achievements, the weariness and frustration from playing both back-to-back will become increasingly apparent.

From a gameplay perspective, NIOH2 does offer a richer experience than NIOH1. It builds upon its predecessor by introducing several interesting new gameplay mechanics and systems, while also refining and improving numerous details from the predecessor. This allows it to maintain a familiar feel while delivering some genuinely fresh gameplay experiences. However, this is largely thanks to NIOH1 establishing such a solid foundation for its gameplay mechanics, enabling NIOH2 to expand upon it. Second, NIOH2 fundamentally retains the gameplay systems of NIOH1. Consequently, despite the new additions, this sense of novelty doesn't last long. Take my experience as an example: I just finished replaying NIOH1 and unlocked all achievements, then dove straight into NIOH2. The freshness and enthusiasm it offered faded almost completely within 20 hours. Instead, an increasingly palpable sense of frustration and fatigue took hold. After all, NIOH2 essentially amounts to a copy-paste of its predecessor‚Äîwhether in its action mechanics, combat system, map design, or core gameplay, it remains virtually identical to the original. Third, in my view, not all of NIOH2's adjustments and changes to the predecessor deliver a better experience. For certain gameplay elements, I personally still prefer the settings of the NIOH1.

From a narrative standpoint, I find NIOH1's story more compelling. NIOH2's plot unfolds before the events of the first game, functioning as a prequel. NIOH1, however, is set during the late Sengoku period of Japan, weaving a rich ensemble tale through the eyes of William Adams (Miura Anjin). This era of Japanese history gave birth to numerous legendary figures. NIOH1 masterfully weaves these elements into a fantastical saga of the late Sengoku period's warlords. In contrast, NIOH2's historical backdrop feels comparatively muted. It adopts anime-inspired tropes and JRPG narrative techniques, focusing its storytelling on a core group led by the protagonist to reflect the era through intimate details. While this narrative style differs from its predecessor and has its own merits, its overly familiar tropes inevitably feel tiresome. Furthermore, the game repeatedly emphasizes themes commonplace in Japanese anime by its later stages: mutual understanding, harmonious coexistence, and letting go of hatred. While NIOH1 touched upon similar themes, it did so subtly and integrated them seamlessly into the plot. Personally, I preferred NIOH1's ensemble-driven narrative, which delivered a sense of grandeur and epic storytelling. In NIOH2, the plot truly began to feel compelling only towards the end of the main story, when William's return brought all the nostalgia and memories from the first game flooding back. Unfortunately, by this point, the game was essentially over. As for the DLC content, it objectively fills in some gaps in the game's lore and setting, making certain elements more logically consistent. But ultimately, it devolves into a rather melodramatic family saga‚Äîthe legendary arch-villain turns out to be the protagonist's mother's brother, and all the fighting boils down to familial grudges and fated enmity...


In summary, NIOH2 is objectively a masterpiece not to be missed, and I highly recommend it. Subjectively, however, my prolonged marathon playthrough of both games left me fatigued, affecting my enjoyment of NIOH2. That said, purely in terms of unlocking all achievements, NIOH2 is considerably easier than NIOH1. Consequently, I only played through NIOH2 once with serious dedication, then unlocked all achievements as quickly as possible, and then decided to take a break. I won't be revisiting NIOH2 for quite some time. Therefore, I personally recommend that if you've just finished playing NIOH1 and played it very seriously, you might want to take a break before starting NIOH2. This approach will give you more freshness and sustain your enthusiasm for longer, making it less likely to burn out quickly. Beyond that, NIOH2 remains an excellent game.

I have heard people say that this soulslike is not what you should start out in and granted I started with Demon Souls on the PS3. However, this game teaches good fundamentals, like timing, ki/stamina and life management, build making etc, that gamers can use in other games that are similarly difficult (Sekiro/Elden Ring). I'd say it is definitely a game that people who are new or relatively experienced in the genre should consider, due to its robust systems.

The nice thing about this game is that you can also have up to two additional players assisting you via invites, you can also summon npc versions of players to help too if no one is around. There are no invasions in this game so you don't have to worry about that if you don't like it.

The game is both fast and slow paced, which sounds odd but it is the best way to describe it. Whilst fighting bosses in the higher difficulties you will be using different methods to take them out and this usually involves in applying a lot of pressure at the right time. The right time does not always present itself regularly and if you get to greedy it can find yourself right back at the shrine. Once you understand this pacing along with understanding the diverse tools available to you to despatch your foes, everything will click for you.

Don't be afraid to experiment, fail, try a different approach, succeed or fail again, refine your approach and ultimately succeed. 

My only issue that I have with this game which is quite specific is that the developers only allow the inventory filter function when in certain menus. The problem is that this game does require quite a lot of inventory management so it is unintuitive to have to go to these menus that you may not want to use just to filter items. It would be nice to open my inventory from the overworld and manage it using filters more efficiently. 

I would ultimately give this game a 9-9.5/10.

It's a very unique game that combines elements from Hack & Slash action games, Soulslike games and Diablo-style ARPGs. 

Lots of weapon combos and many different weapon types that each have their own very distinct playstyles.

Slower and more methodical combat with a heavy focus on its unique stamina management system (Ki Pulse). 

Metroidvania-like map design (some of the larger maps are very well designed and very complex in a good way). 

Bonfire-like safe spots called Shrines where you respawn when you die (yes, enemies respawn as well). 

Stats to level up like you'd do in Soulslike games and lots of gear grind like in an old school ARPG (so no unique armor and weapons like in Soulslike games but randomized Diablo-style loot).

There are also other types of offensive abilities besides the weapons and their related skills and combos. 

There is Ninjutsu ( do not think I have to explain this one) and Onmyo (a type of traditional magic from Japanese folklore that is like a combination of elemental and holy magic. Think of Shamanism and Exorcism in one). Both are very much viable to include in builds and come with their own skill trees similar to the weapon skill trees.

Then there is Yokai Shift and Yokai abilities. Yokai are spirits from Japanese folklore. Most of them seem to be evil, but there are also neutral one and good ones. Yokai Shift is a transformation that brings out your inner Yokai (the good kind) that comes with greatly enhanched abilities. You can have a total of two guardian spirits at a time, each of which come in three different types (Brute, Feral and Phantom) and with their own stats (not random).

When you beat evil Yokai they have a chance to leave behind a Soul Core which you can equip in your Guardian Spirits which allows you to use the abilities of these Yokai. Soul Core stats are mostly random, but each type of Yokai does have specific guaranteed stats that are always the same for that type of Yokai. You are very much encouraged to use these and it's a lot of fun to weave them in between your weapon combos. You can use them independently from your Yokai Shift. You can farm Soul Cores infinitely and there are ways to increase the drop rates. There are a bunch of maps that are especially good for Soul Core farming.

All in all I'd say that calling the Nioh games Soulslike does not do these games justice. There are certainly elements of Soulslike games. But as I explained above it does a lot to set itself apart from the standard Soulslike formula. And in my opinion it does so in a very good way.

The game does have some negatives. What I disliked the most were the difficulty spikes. There are certain parts throughout the story were the difficulty will feel very out of wack compared to the parts you just completed. One of these spikes occurs rather early, in the second main mission. It's very much beatable, but for those who tend to struggle at such parts (like I do) then this can become a source for frustration. 

But that's where the gear grind can help you out. In this game gear matters a lot, but in a very different way than you'd find in a more traditional Soulslike game. This is where the Diablo-like ARPG elements come in. Lots and lots of randomized gear of different rarities, and there is also gear crafting. A multitude of different gear sets that come with their own bonuses are also present. Exactly like you'd expect from a Diablo-style ARPG. 

You do not get a weapon and a set of armor and then stick with it for the rest of the game. You will want to get new weapons and new armor on a regular basis. You will play this game as if it were a more traditional Soulslike at your own peril. Play it like Grim Dawn instead of Lords of the Fallen.

One thing that I'm more neutral on is the story. It takes place in the Sengoku Era and includes iconic figures from Japanese history such as Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and these are very much relevant to the plot (especially Hideyoshi). Then as a bonus it throws in a lot of supernatural and spiritual elements from Japanese folklore and mythology into the mix. 

So you'd think that this whole setting would be perfect for an incredible story. But the overall presentation kind of falls flat in my opinion. It all appear like a selection of historical events that, while they progress in chronological order, still feel somehow like they were randomly thrown together. And then your own character, the random no-name character that you just created out of thin air, is awkwardly hamfisted in between all these renowned historical figures.

But I generally do not play these types of games for the story so I didn't bother to look into all the subtext, and therefore I opted to remain neutral towards it.

Now visually the whole setting truly comes to life. I personally love how the historical and folklorist/mythological elements are woven into one another. The game oozes atmosphere, especially on the larger and more complex maps. I think the game aged very well. Yet another piece of evidence in favor of the idea that art style can carry the visuals of a game far further into the future than pure graphical fidelity can.

And last but not least, while I'm not at that point in the game yet, there is a very extensive endgame grind at the end of the story. The DLCs included with this edition of the game expand on this endgame. So if you love grinding and optimizing gear and learning the ins and outs of your preferred weapons and abilities, and put it all to the test against overwhelming odds then there is certainly fun to be had in this game. And then there is also NG+. So lots of replayability and plenty of chances to try out different builds and playstyles.

There is no PvP. But you can fight against Revenants, which are basically copies of other players left behind after they die. There is a sort of clan system that mostly exists to provide some useful passive QoL bonuses. You can fight these Revenants to increase your score and increase your passive bonuses. There is Co-Op and you can voluntarly leave bind a copy of yourself in three maps of your choice that other players can summon to help them out.

All things considered, I will say that I personally highly recommend this game. I think it's very fun and sets itself apart from other games very nicely. The mixture of Japanese history and Folklore/Mythology provides a very distinct style and atmosphere that I personally really like.

This is one of my GOATs. It's old now, very old. From the get go, it had great graphics for its time, but not just that, it had absolutely, insanely well optimized graphics. Multiple NG+ tiers each with their own scaling and introducing more loot tiers and new sets as you dig deeper. Finishing NG is just the start. Then you get into NG+ and start tuning weapons, farming for endgame sets, memorizing boss move pools, etc. While it doesn't have the open world nature of a more traditional Souls-like, the linear, level-like layout allows them to have absolutely stellar and tight level design and layouts, and frankly the only blemish on the game's levels is their occasional reuse for smaller side missions. I won't begrudge them that though, since they added multiple new weapon types, discoverable secret moves, and full character customization in their second iteration of Nioh.

TLDR: If you're looking for a game that has deep combat/mechanics, a lot of cool enemy designs, banger soundtrack and endless content... Nioh 2 is a no-brainer, must-play.

However, if you intend to thoroughly explore every detail, play through at least four times, and ultimately unlock all achievements, the weariness and frustration from playing both back-to-back will become increasingly apparent.

From a gameplay perspective, NIOH2 does offer a richer experience than NIOH1. It builds upon its predecessor by introducing several interesting new gameplay mechanics and systems, while also refining and improving numerous details from the predecessor. This allows it to maintain a familiar feel while delivering some genuinely fresh gameplay experiences. However, this is largely thanks to NIOH1 establishing such a solid foundation for its gameplay mechanics, enabling NIOH2 to expand upon it. Second, NIOH2 fundamentally retains the gameplay systems of NIOH1. Consequently, despite the new additions, this sense of novelty doesn't last long. Take my experience as an example: I just finished replaying NIOH1 and unlocked all achievements, then dove straight into NIOH2. The freshness and enthusiasm it offered faded almost completely within 20 hours. Instead, an increasingly palpable sense of frustration and fatigue took hold. After all, NIOH2 essentially amounts to a copy-paste of its predecessor‚Äîwhether in its action mechanics, combat system, map design, or core gameplay, it remains virtually identical to the original. Third, in my view, not all of NIOH2's adjustments and changes to the predecessor deliver a better experience. For certain gameplay elements, I personally still prefer the settings of the NIOH1.

From a narrative standpoint, I find NIOH1's story more compelling. NIOH2's plot unfolds before the events of the first game, functioning as a prequel. NIOH1, however, is set during the late Sengoku period of Japan, weaving a rich ensemble tale through the eyes of William Adams (Miura Anjin). This era of Japanese history gave birth to numerous legendary figures. NIOH1 masterfully weaves these elements into a fantastical saga of the late Sengoku period's warlords. In contrast, NIOH2's historical backdrop feels comparatively muted. It adopts anime-inspired tropes and JRPG narrative techniques, focusing its storytelling on a core group led by the protagonist to reflect the era through intimate details. While this narrative style differs from its predecessor and has its own merits, its overly familiar tropes inevitably feel tiresome. Furthermore, the game repeatedly emphasizes themes commonplace in Japanese anime by its later stages: mutual understanding, harmonious coexistence, and letting go of hatred. While NIOH1 touched upon similar themes, it did so subtly and integrated them seamlessly into the plot. Personally, I preferred NIOH1's ensemble-driven narrative, which delivered a sense of grandeur and epic storytelling. In NIOH2, the plot truly began to feel compelling only towards the end of the main story, when William's return brought all the nostalgia and memories from the first game flooding back. Unfortunately, by this point, the game was essentially over. As for the DLC content, it objectively fills in some gaps in the game's lore and setting, making certain elements more logically consistent. But ultimately, it devolves into a rather melodramatic family saga‚Äîthe legendary arch-villain turns out to be the protagonist's mother's brother, and all the fighting boils down to familial grudges and fated enmity...


In summary, NIOH2 is objectively a masterpiece not to be missed, and I highly recommend it. Subjectively, however, my prolonged marathon playthrough of both games left me fatigued, affecting my enjoyment of NIOH2. That said, purely in terms of unlocking all achievements, NIOH2 is considerably easier than NIOH1. Consequently, I only played through NIOH2 once with serious dedication, then unlocked all achievements as quickly as possible, and then decided to take a break. I won't be revisiting NIOH2 for quite some time. Therefore, I personally recommend that if you've just finished playing NIOH1 and played it very seriously, you might want to take a break before starting NIOH2. This approach will give you more freshness and sustain your enthusiasm for longer, making it less likely to burn out quickly. Beyond that, NIOH2 remains an excellent game.

Nioh 2 is my favourite action RPG ever. It's a mission-based hack and slash looter with a focus on player movesets. Missions are anywhere from 2 minutes to half an hour, so there's not too much time commitment needed. Its combat systems are too deep to go into in one small review, but it builds off of Nioh's excellent three-stance system and adds in various awesome Yokai abilities that lets you turn into a demon, summon Yokai to help or brutally counter enemy attacks. If you want a gameplay comparison, it's like Ninja Gaiden and Musou had a Diablo baby. There's 11 weapons and they're all incredibly deep and you'll take ages to master their enormous movesets. The graphics are fantastic and the game's artstyle goes so hard, with combat feeling very frantic as particle effects fly in every direction and there's constant explosions and magical effects. Not to mention the absolutely awesome enemies and bosses, of which there are many. The story is more than serviceable and puts you in the shoes of a very famous 16th century Japanese warlord. I won't spoil much more but it's got some awesome moments and even made me cry once or twice. After you finish the 50-70 hour campaign, there's hundreds of hours of endgame content across the game's 4 NG+ cycles, and the gigantic final dungeon unlocked after that. The endgame isn't for the faint of heart - it's designed to be unfair and feel impossible at times, but it does this without artificial padding. You are never far from your mission objective. However, even missions that would be considered boring in other games are just more excuse to interact with the game's insane combat system that you'll never get bored of.

If you're not a fan of the Sengoku era, you likely won't understand the story much, so go in expecting that. Also, sometimes the game can feel a little bit difficult, but you have the option of asking other players for help or summoning player-created NPC bodyguards to assist you. There's one or two bosses I don't like, with one of the later bosses being a bit obnoxious if you go alone. Lastly, the game doesn't do an amazing job of introducing mechanics slowly to the player, meaning you can definitely feel thrown in the deep end and find yourself dying a fair bit, but just remember that levels don't matter much in this game and you gain permanent experience every time you hit an enemy. 

Overall, this is easily my favourite game ever. I've played close to a thousand hours of it on all systems, and I don't intend to stop. No combat system has ever come close, and this game is such a wild improvement over what was already one of my favourite games ever.

Three new major introductions to the sequel are Yokai Realms, Burst Counters, and soul cores. Yokai Realms are great fun : fog-shrouded areas filled with powerful enemies that reduced ki recovery until the ‚Äúboss‚Äù of the area is found and dealt with. You really have to plan your attack carefully and not run in guns blazing, which was a refreshing change from the rest of the levels.

Soul cores I was a bit lukewarm on. It‚Äôs a great idea in theory, allowing you to effectively steal an enemy‚Äôs move-set and add it to your own, but in practice I quickly found my three favourites, then didn‚Äôt touch it again until the endgame.

Unfortunately, there are the other things that still need to be fixed. Loot is still a hassle to deal with. The forge (or reforge), I found to be mostly useless on the lower difficulty levels. It's a very unique game that combines elements from Hack & Slash action games, Soulslike games and Diablo-style ARPGs. 

Lots of weapon combos and many different weapon types that each have their own very distinct playstyles.

Slower and more methodical combat with a heavy focus on its unique stamina management system (Ki Pulse). 

Metroidvania-like map design (some of the larger maps are very well designed and very complex in a good way). 

Bonfire-like safe spots called Shrines where you respawn when you die (yes, enemies respawn as well). 

Stats to level up like you'd do in Soulslike games and lots of gear grind like in an old school ARPG (so no unique armor and weapons like in Soulslike games but randomized Diablo-style loot).

There are also other types of offensive abilities besides the weapons and their related skills and combos. 

There is Ninjutsu ( do not think I have to explain this one) and Onmyo (a type of traditional magic from Japanese folklore that is like a combination of elemental and holy magic. Think of Shamanism and Exorcism in one). Both are very much viable to include in builds and come with their own skill trees similar to the weapon skill trees.

Then there is Yokai Shift and Yokai abilities. Yokai are spirits from Japanese folklore. Most of them seem to be evil, but there are also neutral one and good ones. Yokai Shift is a transformation that brings out your inner Yokai (the good kind) that comes with greatly enhanched abilities. You can have a total of two guardian spirits at a time, each of which come in three different types (Brute, Feral and Phantom) and with their own stats (not random).

When you beat evil Yokai they have a chance to leave behind a Soul Core which you can equip in your Guardian Spirits which allows you to use the abilities of these Yokai. Soul Core stats are mostly random, but each type of Yokai does have specific guaranteed stats that are always the same for that type of Yokai. You are very much encouraged to use these and it's a lot of fun to weave them in between your weapon combos. You can use them independently from your Yokai Shift. You can farm Soul Cores infinitely and there are ways to increase the drop rates. There are a bunch of maps that are especially good for Soul Core farming.

All in all I'd say that calling the Nioh games Soulslike does not do these games justice. There are certainly elements of Soulslike games. But as I explained above it does a lot to set itself apart from the standard Soulslike formula. And in my opinion it does so in a very good way.

The game does have some negatives. What I disliked the most were the difficulty spikes. There are certain parts throughout the story were the difficulty will feel very out of wack compared to the parts you just completed. One of these spikes occurs rather early, in the second main mission. It's very much beatable, but for those who tend to struggle at such parts (like I do) then this can become a source for frustration. 

But that's where the gear grind can help you out. In this game gear matters a lot, but in a very different way than you'd find in a more traditional Soulslike game. This is where the Diablo-like ARPG elements come in. Lots and lots of randomized gear of different rarities, and there is also gear crafting. A multitude of different gear sets that come with their own bonuses are also present. Exactly like you'd expect from a Diablo-style ARPG. 

You do not get a weapon and a set of armor and then stick with it for the rest of the game. You will want to get new weapons and new armor on a regular basis. You will play this game as if it were a more traditional Soulslike at your own peril. Play it like Grim Dawn instead of Lords of the Fallen.

One thing that I'm more neutral on is the story. It takes place in the Sengoku Era and includes iconic figures from Japanese history such as Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and these are very much relevant to the plot (especially Hideyoshi). Then as a bonus it throws in a lot of supernatural and spiritual elements from Japanese folklore and mythology into the mix. 

So you'd think that this whole setting would be perfect for an incredible story. But the overall presentation kind of falls flat in my opinion. It all appear like a selection of historical events that, while they progress in chronological order, still feel somehow like they were randomly thrown together. And then your own character, the random no-name character that you just created out of thin air, is awkwardly hamfisted in between all these renowned historical figures.

But I generally do not play these types of games for the story so I didn't bother to look into all the subtext, and therefore I opted to remain neutral towards it.

Now visually the whole setting truly comes to life. I personally love how the historical and folklorist/mythological elements are woven into one another. The game oozes atmosphere, especially on the larger and more complex maps. I think the game aged very well. Yet another piece of evidence in favor of the idea that art style can carry the visuals of a game far further into the future than pure graphical fidelity can.

And last but not least, while I'm not at that point in the game yet, there is a very extensive endgame grind at the end of the story. The DLCs included with this edition of the game expand on this endgame. So if you love grinding and optimizing gear and learning the ins and outs of your preferred weapons and abilities, and put it all to the test against overwhelming odds then there is certainly fun to be had in this game. And then there is also NG+. So lots of replayability and plenty of chances to try out different builds and playstyles.

There is no PvP. But you can fight against Revenants, which are basically copies of other players left behind after they die. There is a sort of clan system that mostly exists to provide some useful passive QoL bonuses. You can fight these Revenants to increase your score and increase your passive bonuses. There is Co-Op and you can voluntarly leave bind a copy of yourself in three maps of your choice that other players can summon to help them out.

All things considered, I will say that I personally highly recommend this game. I think it's very fun and sets itself apart from other games very nicely. The mixture of Japanese history and Folklore/Mythology provides a very distinct style and atmosphere that I personally really like.

I really loved the first Nioh, though I did not play it on Steam, and I'm not sure I'm going to revisit it since they are both hand-killers.

I was super excited when my partner and I got the sequel, and it mostly surpasses the original in every way, though there are a few negatives.

Unfortunately, most of the negatives hit you right up-front. The story (well, at least until the halfway mark) is not as strong as the first. Towards the end, I felt that it surpassed Nioh 1.

It also doesn't play the best on a Steam Deck, though I completed the game entirely on that device. The resolution has to be kept very low, and it's still pretty blurry. It was enjoyable to me to play this on a large screen tv, but not everyone will share my taste for this.

Inventory Management is very bad, much worse than the first game, and you will encounter this fairly early into the game, and it will remain a pain throughout your playtime. Towards the end, I basically just kept a lookout for a few particular sets, and had to smash everything in one go to save both my sanity and my hands. I probably lost a lot of good equipment that way. 

The last negative is that I did not like the changes to magic/livingweapon/spirits (I forget all of the terminology, I apologize). It made them tied to the gear too much, and coupled with the inventory management, I wound up again just not changing too much here once I found things I liked.

Something that I would say is neither a pro or a con is the difficulty. It's gravely difficult, so difficult many people will quit early on, but I don't think it's unfair. Conversely, I think the difficulty is unbelievably balanced and rewarding. You will feel yourself getting better and you will see the results in-game. I would say that a few of the final fights (and final dlc fights) are just kinda ridiculous and I'm glad I did not grind those for gear haha!

For difficulty references, I am kind of all over the place. I found Elden Ring super easy and got 100%, but Vernal Edge might be the hardest game ever for me!

Now to the positives!

The graphics, though heavily damaged on the Steam Deck, are still gorgeous. The game has a sense of grandeur and scale that almost no other game does (though Nioh 1 also did this really well!). You will frequently overlook huge vistas of sprawling shanty-towns, rolling hills, and warped crystalline structures. I don't want to spoil too much of the end-game locations, but fans of the first game can expect the same AND MORE!

The maps are crazy-good. Master class. You might find an odd glitch or fall through a texture every now and then (very rare), but there is just so much to like about these maps. They are logically laid out and always varied enough that you can orient yourself quite easily (most of the time) just by visual landmarks. Maps progress logically, telling a story. There are numerous little hidden alcoves and nooks and fake walls. And there are hints a-plenty to almost all of them. The maps are just amazing in this game.

The combat is I guess the last thing I can talk about. And that's a good thing, because the combat is even better than the maps. Once you get into a groove, it just sings. Two enemies at once are a death sentence in your first hour. Ten hours later, you will be ambushed by five ninjas and 2 ogres and a snake miniboss in a room the size of an elevator, and also the floor is lava, and you'll casually check your ninjitsu loadout numbers and just smirk. It's a testament to the combat system that I cannot pick a favorite weapon. I also cannot pick a least favorite weapon. I played every weapon and I enjoyed each one. They are all so different and unique and it was truly a joy unlocking ALL (yes, I'm crazy) of the arts for every weapon!

I guess one final thing is, don't play this if you like your hands. They will be mean to you after this game.

And also, thank you for reading this far!

Nioh 2 is a game where you play as a sickly anemia patient with chronic fatigue. Feel the exhilaration of waiting 3-5 business days for your stamina to refill after swinging your sword two times. Revel in the excitement of watching your entire stamina bar disappear halfway through dodging a single combo.

To be clear, I am on the fence with this game. Yes, I did "beat" NG+1. No, I did not love every minute of Nioh 2. If I wasn't playing co-op I would have dropped Nioh 2 after the credits rolled. For every thing that Nioh 2 does really well, it does something else equally horribly wrong. The level design is way more involved and intentional than in Dark Souls, but these levels are also really long and it's easy to miss collectables or side-quest tasks. Equipment is interesting yet not restricting in what you can use, but getting a specific kind of weapon means potentially hours of grinding for recipes. 

The most prominent thing about Nioh is the combat, and here its a mixed bag as well. There are lots of cool active skills, but only one or two per weapon (anything that can kick, especially) are really good, and you will SPAM them. Burst counters should reward reactions and timing, but those timings are inconsistent: am I supposed to burst when this guy right away, or when he dashes at me, or when he tries to slash me? Get it wrong and you'll INSTANTLY DIE. This game is definitely a victim of "hard = good", enemy ambushes that can kill you in two hits. Enemies randomly get hyper armor and kill you in two hits. Enemies have unreactable command grabs which nearly kills you and leaves you vulnerable to a follow-up. Run out of ki and instantly die. Get paralyzed by a goblin during your OWN critical hit animation and instantly die. I hated the dojo fights, as well.

I beat all of NG+0 by doing light attacks->stance change ki pulse->repeat or kick->stagger->iai slash->grapple->repeat. The stance system's only obvious use is to hit Yokai weak points and maybe(?) high attacks breaking guards easier. If there are nuances to the three stances, they aren't explained well. Low stance is "defensive" but high stance has the most usable roll. High stance is "aggressive" but its attacks are suited for poking where low stance has fast attacks that let you play close to the enemy.

While it's nice that NG+ actually adds content in Nioh 2, once I hit NG+2 (Dream of the Demon) I decided I was done with the game. I blasted through the NG+1 final boss, so I thought I was going to be fine in NG+2, oh how wrong I was. The enemies become far too tanky and you are basically required to either master the game like it's your crack addiction, or abuse damage multipliers from skills/confusion to progress. The entire NG+0 could be beaten by playing smart and just using regular attacks, but in NG+ it's gimmick city. To be clear, I am on the fence with this game. Yes, I did "beat" NG+1. No, I did not love every minute of Nioh 2. If I wasn't playing co-op I would have dropped Nioh 2 after the credits rolled. For every thing that Nioh 2 does really well, it does something else equally horribly wrong. The level design is way more involved and intentional than in Dark Souls, but these levels are also really long and it's easy to miss collectables or side-quest tasks. Equipment is interesting yet not restricting in what you can use, but getting a specific kind of weapon means potentially hours of grinding for recipes. 

The most prominent thing about Nioh is the combat, and here its a mixed bag as well. There are lots of cool active skills, but only one or two per weapon (anything that can kick, especially) are really good, and you will SPAM them. Burst counters should reward reactions and timing, but those timings are inconsistent: am I supposed to burst when this guy right away, or when he dashes at me, or when he tries to slash me? Get it wrong and you'll INSTANTLY DIE. This game is definitely a victim of "hard = good", enemy ambushes that can kill you in two hits. Enemies randomly get hyper armor and kill you in two hits. Enemies have unreactable command grabs which nearly kills you and leaves you vulnerable to a follow-up. Run out of ki and instantly die. Get paralyzed by a goblin during your OWN critical hit animation and instantly die. I hated the dojo fights, as well.

I beat all of NG+0 by doing light attacks->stance change ki pulse->repeat or kick->stagger->iai slash->grapple->repeat. The stance system's only obvious use is to hit Yokai weak points and maybe(?) high attacks breaking guards easier. If there are nuances to the three stances, they aren't explained well. Low stance is "defensive" but high stance has the most usable roll. High stance is "aggressive" but its attacks are suited for poking where low stance has fast attacks that let you play close to the enemy.

While it's nice that NG+ actually adds content in Nioh 2, once I hit NG+2 (Dream of the Demon) I decided I was done with the game. I blasted through the NG+1 final boss, so I thought I was going to be fine in NG+2, oh how wrong I was. The enemies become far too tanky and you are basically required to either master the game like it's your crack addiction, or abuse damage multipliers from skills/confusion to progress. The entire NG+0 could be beaten by playing smart and just using regular attacks, but in NG+ it's gimmick city. It's a shame, because apparently there's even MORE content in the later NG+ cycles, but I cannot be bothered anymore.

Overall it took me about 60 hours to beat the main story and half of the side missions, have not done the DLC. I thought the actual plot was cool, if a little rushed by the end. I'm not a history buff, but I thought the pseudo-historical retelling was cool and reflected the concept of the Nio (folklore) well. If you agree with the sentiment that "hard = good" then give Nioh 2 a try, but I honestly think the vast majority of people will be better off not spending so much of their time trying to master a game that doesn't respect yours. This is an exhausting game.

Starts promising but quickly falls into the same pitfalls as Nioh 1. It's even hard to call it a proper sequel, with the amount of reused enemies, bosses, and maps. The game feels more like Nioh 1.5. Here are some of the biggest issues:
* Game still throws at you a massive amount of trash loot that you then have to dispose of manually. Searching for a particular piece of equipment is a real pain in the ass, especially when you try to get set bonuses.
* It feels like around half of the enemies are reused from the previous game with a very little change to them. There are also reused bosses and maps, but to a much lesser degree.
* Main missions format feels stale, especially after completing Nioh 1. Nothing interesting happens during missions. In the first game, at least there were some events like for example battlefields.
* I didn't like the way you get proficiency points. To get any meaningful progress in onmyo or ninjutsu tree you have to spam abilities all the time. It's also hard to try a new weapon type. You can't just relocate points, you have to start from the scratch.
 * I liked the enemy design at first, but it gets more and more stupid as you progress the game, with the final dlc being a cherry on top. Some of them are REALLY annoying and tiresome to deal with.
* Yokai bosses were mostly great, but human bosses are trash. They don't seem to play by the same rules. For example, they can regenerate ki while being hit, cast spells without interruption, be unstaggered as they like, or just throw at you an instant grab attack.
* Enemy placement is terrible, with constant ambushes every 10m. It makes exploring levels a slog.

Some positives worth mentioning:
* Story got better, same with the characters.
* Improved combat - more moves, spells, yokai shift is much better and fun than living weapon from Nioh 1.
* Overall well designed yokai bosses.
